in 2020-2021 i wrote a diploma about alternative technologies in black and white landscape photography in which i used cyanotypia as a main technique for the project (cyan-II to be exact, i had to make it as less toxic or polluting as possible and the II type is claimed to be non toxic and biodegradable, although i'd still not drink it), but i decided at the last moment to exclude toning from the work for i was running out of time due to many takes on printing and optimizing it.
i used Ansel Adams' theoretical works about perfect negative developing as a base, the thing you did in the video (step-test), but slightly more complex and detailed, and to make said negatives i also had to make my prints as high quality as i could afford, so i ordered a... i don't know what the term would be in english, but to translate it literally, it's a photo output for offset printing.

unfortunately i got so worn out so it started to feel extremely mundane and predictable, so i abandoned it for who knows how long.
nonetheless i would definitely recommend you to try wet cyanotype with soap solution or/and citric acid crystals or/and botanicals (fresh and dried leaves, wet ones have said tannins in them so it gives very interesting effects), i seriously cannot recall if you mentioned it or not, but just in case, try vinegar as a tone softener next time you overexpose, as far as i remember it does exactly that but to a certain point of no return ofc.

also, i found out that my top favorite toners are the next ones (i can look up my notes for proportions if needed):
- oak bark
- willow-herb
- technical tannin powder (as it gives proper clean results)

i'd also recommend combining toners to tone the picture twice, as one toner for example gives more green tones and the other one tends to taint to red tones, when applied one after another or all at once it might give nice neutral results, or give you different tones etc.

also i used four strong UV lamps and a softbox from a studio light (without a softening fabric)? so the exposure time was about 2:30 minutes each piece

Not accounting for reciprocity failure... if you come back to this, try f-stop timing. I do half-stop test strips which are at intervals derived from sqrt(2), which I use standard f/stop numbers as a reference for - 4, 5.6 (I just use 6 seconds on darkroom prints), 8, 11, 16, 22, 32. Because sensitometry (which I do not understand but I do respect) the exposure difference between each of these half-stop steps is approximately equal (this is why camera shutter speeds count in doubles instead of linearly too), and you can chop up the stops between powers of two in other ways - third stops are also common and use the cube root of 2, which gives you (for example) roughly 8, 10, 12.7, 16.

My friends and I are artists and my friend specializes in watercolour, so here’s a tip from them to me to remove the unevenness of the paper before adding large amounts of liquid.
You first need to treat the paper by submerging it in water, the thinner the paper the short amount of time. In short that part is trait and error since size of the paper affects it too, but once you soaked it till it will bend in four directions and is barely curling (thinner papers are different and this is based on my experiences which is only with medium thickness watercolour paper) so you leave it out to dry. After that you flatten it under many heavy objects (the one in contact with the paper must be at least the same size and flat as well, ideally larger) once it’s flat and COMPLETELY DRY you should have a piece of paper that won’t curl. This is just my personal experience and it WILL NOT work with anything as thin as or thinner than printer paper so you have been notified.
Hope this helps!!!

That observation about how the longer the exposure the lower the concentration of unexposed FAC there is is similar to the concept of reciprocity failure in film photography. Basically, during long exposures the longer you expose the film, the less of the emulsion is still light sensitive and you have to account for that depending on your film.

Hey! The stuff you're describing around 13:00 is called reciprocity failure, and it's common to see with film photography, especially black and white film has this failure higher (but this is not a rule!). You can also find it under "schwarzschild law"

This process is all about making printing out paper or POP for short.  A century ago, many cameras used large glass plates as film. Some were 8X10-inches in size or larger, and they were placed in a printing frame with a sheet of POP and taken into the sunlight. When the paper turned a particular color, it was taken to the darkroom and processed. Some of the best quality photos of all time were printed in this manner. You do need to size the paper, and use the best quality paper possible. Paper that is made from rags and acid free is what you need for quality prints. A UV lamp would make your printing process more repeatable. Also, there is another printing process based on platinum. You can see prints made this way in museums.

Here are a couple tips that I think could help. The negative is one of the most important things so you can convert the color image into a halftone first before inverting to a negative. This will allow you to adjust your levels more equally for just a single color exposure like your doing here or even for the duo tone. Also place the emulsion side of your negative closest to the paper, this will allow for less uv light to "bleed" under the blacked out portions which is a result of the very minute thickness of the transparent layer and you can also buy thinner transparency to reduce the amount of uv light to bleed. The closer you can get your negative to lay to the paper the better your result will be. In the print shop we vacume the negative down to the paper to get it as close as possible. Makes a huge difference. Also you could try a lower dpi "dots per inch" on the printer when printing the negative. Sometimes higher dpi washes out even though it's better quality some paper just can't hold it so try lowering the dpi to like 300 or 200 or 150 and see the difference in results. These are all things you can do that I feel would really help. I think it would be awesome to get some blueprints with lots of linework to expose. Like the Eiffel tower or the colleseum.

The degrading sensitivity of the photosensitive material is during exposure called Schwazschild-Effect, at least in German, there doesn't seem to be a direct translation?! And you are right, it's exponential. There are different exponents for different photosenitive materials. This all was important during the days of chemical astrophotography. There was a photographic film called Kodak Technical Pan 2415, that was the holy grail of technical and astronomical photography. It was monochrome but had a Schwarzschild-Exponent relatively close to 1 (at least in comparison to other chemical films wich were waay worse). Now with electronic sensors you have Schwarzschild-Exponents very close to 1, giving essentially a linear relationship between exposure and sensor readout. You can't imagine how happy that made astrophotographers! :D
With colour films you had a different Schwarzschild-Exponent for every colour, so long exposure astrophotographs were never ever even close to a balanced colour. But that actually didn't matter that much in aesthetic astropotography.
There was also the practice of hypersensetising film material. I'm not really sure about the chemistry behind that but you usually put the material into a pressurised hydrogen atmosphere at elevated temperature for some hours. That got the Schwarzschild Exponent closer to 1 and/or made the whole film more sensitive but you had to take your photographs soon after.

The non-linear exposure response over time has been known for a very long time in the film world. A specific example is film-make star trail images. If an exposure is made over 2 hours, the stars move, making a trail for each visible star. However, on film, each trail begins to fade out, as the exposure time / effect begins to diminish. This effect is called reciprocity failure, and is exactly what you describe here. Charts are/were even distributed to help photographers deal with the phenomenon on long exposures.

there is something major you are missing in your discussion: cyanotypes do not develop on a linear range, the way silver salts do. You will never get anything other than an either full dark or pure white. Cyanotypes are an extremely high contrast process. in order to get around this, you have to use a method to break down your greys into a halftone image, either by photoshop, or doing a pre-exposure to a halftone screen....since we live in the very boring digital age, good luck trying to locate a screen.

So I don't know much about chemistry, but I've been experimenting with making Rochelle salt crystals to do some testing with the piezoelectric effect.

So the procedure I've seen basically uses baking soda, cooking it in a 400 degree oven to make soda ash. Then heating up a glass of water (I used deer park bottled), mixing in cream of tartar, and then adding the soda ash to the cream of tartar water mixture until it turns clear, or at least stops being milky white.

I used about a half bottle of cream of tartar from my spice cabinet and the liquid went clear after only two spoon fulls of the soda ash. Maybe I screw this up because I added more soda ash after it became clear (about 2-3 more spoonfuls).

I think I probably started off using way too much water, I think it was around 2 cups. The resulting mixture has yet to make any crystals. I figured there might be too much water, so I boiled it down to a smaller amount, but I don't know if this would have changed the chemistry significantly. In film development there's a process called "stand development" that amplifies this ingredient consumption effect for a useful purpose.  By developing film in a lower concentration of developer, longer, and without agitation, the development of the silver grains will locally exhaust the solution slowing the reaction while less developed areas catch up.  The resulting film has a lower contrast and a maximized recorded dynamic range preserving detail in shadow and highlights and allowing the choice of what to sacrifice for pleasing contrast to be delayed until printing.

Instead of starting with a photo, I would print a "reference negative" containing pre-defined gray levels (10%, 25%, 50%, 75%) as well as white-on-black and black-on-white parts, some test strips with varying sizes. There are such test images already avaiable for lens calibration.

Then you can measure max and min blue level achievable by the method and map that to black and white. Finally, once you have the mapping, you can quantitatively evaluate cyanotype development quality. This will depend on all the parameters you find to be important (amount of UV irradiation, amount of chemical I and II) and with that, you can find the optimal parameters by fiddling with parameters, taking samples and then finding the best ones with some nonliner optimization method (there are scientific toolboxes for that).

I always enjoy your videos greatly, but this one is, as of yet, my favorite video of yours.

Some years ago, I started out with digital photography but not long after moved into film photography and darkroom processes, then followed by historical photographic processes. To see you go through step-by-step the recreating of what was done in the 1860s and on is quite fantastic.

Trying to get the chemistry of the process properly working, to compensate exposure, to test different exposures and times of the day right for UV light, the way you test exposures by exposing the image for different times to check the density...

You even got to the basis of density (Dmax) and reciprocity charts.

It's all exactly what was and still is done in the making of a photographic print. THIS is the basis behind all the research and standardization in the photographic industry, creating UV-exposure units and emulsion-coating. It's what Kodak and Fuji, among many other chemical/photographic industries, did up until quite recently in 2004 when digital started to take over the market.

As I said before, this is a fantastic work and video. Congratulations.

Essentially you'd need to find two complementary chemicals that behave in a similar way, but where there isn't any cross-reaction with previously developed dyes.

Assuming you can find suitable chemicals, you'd have to print 3 negatives, one for each colour channel. (use an image editor to break the image down into CMY component images)

Oh man, this is how I got my interest in chemistry. There are so many different so called “alternative” photo processes. In reality they were mainstream before the advent of commercial silver nitrate printing paper. Some of my favorite, pretty easy processes include vandyke brown and salt prints. Some more complicated but utterly beautiful process include platinum/palladium printing and carbon printing. I do recommend staying away from the traditional daguerreotype process though, inhaling mercury vapors isn’t such a good idea lol.

One thing you didn’t explore is the contrast gradient of your negatives. Toy can’t really eyeball them if you want the best results. Different processes have different inherent contrast ranges and distributions. You can find curves for different processes. If you use ink jet printing you can get more advanced tone mapping plug ins. The idea is that different inks have different UV absorption rates.

There is an enormous number of videos on YouTube if you want to explore the world of alternative photography. So much great photography is now much easier because of digital negatives. Photographer’s formulary and Bostic & Sullivan are both great resources for photographic chemicals.

In chemistry-based photography there is the idea of reciprocity, where exposing film or paper for twice as long at half brightness will give the same exposure. ISO 200 film at 1/500th second is the same as ISO 100 at 1/250th.

But in really long exposures, on the order of above a minute, there is "reciprocity failure": a ten minute exposure isn't the same as a fie minute exposure one stop down. From your experiment it seems like that may apply to cyanotypes too.

I would love to see a video on 6,6'-dibromoindigo, AKA Tyrian purple. A very historically significant dye, and one that was incredibly expensive before it could be synthesized, due to how many snails had to be collected to extract a useful amount of it.

Something you can try from the print industry to control visual contrast is to use halftoning - the original process used a physical dot screen (essentially dots printed on transparency), but you can simulate it using the convert to Blank & White mode in photoshop. the coarser the screen (lower the halftone value), the larger the dots. really low values can create some really cool effects, whereas high numbers will give you more detail.
Essentially, the process you used to create the cyanotype is still used to create offset printing plates in smaller print shops. The larger print shops simply use a laser to bypass most of these steps.

As someone who specializes in alternative process photography, you should adjust your contrast curves in Photoshop (or Gimp) before printing your negative. This website has a great ready-made curve on it for download: https://www.alternativephotography.com/curve-corner-photoshop-curves/

Photographer here. I think the reason exposure time follows an exponential curve is also, in part, due to the nature of how we perceive light. In photography, when the amount of light that hit the sensor (or the cyanotype) double (or halve), we call it a "stop". Why? Because the human eyes see light logarithmically. Say if you have 1 light on and you turn on another light, the room will be significantly brighter, but it won't be twice brighter. Now if you have 10 lights on, and then you turn on 1 more, the difference will be insignificant. The same applies to the exposure time. That means if you change the exposure time linearly, the brightness of the image will change logarithmically following a diminishing curve. You should try again, but with exponentially increasing exposure time (^2). For example, 1,2,4,8,16 minutes.

You mentioned that the relationship between exposure and darkness is not linear. Keep in mind that this is as relevant to exposure by attenuation as it is to exposure by time. That is, if it's not quite half as dark after half the time in the sun, it's also not quite half as dark after the same amount of time in half-tinted transparency.

The solution to drawing out the details in your final prints is to use tone curves when preparing your negatives. My suggestion would be to prepare a Photoshop document that has a gradient from "black" to "white", along with a series of half-tone patterns. Print that out, set it out in the sunlight until you get a decent amount of exposure, then develop. Then go back into your Photoshop document, and on top of the layer containing the gradients and half-tone patterns, add a "Gradient Map" layer. Adjust the colors on this gradient map until what you see on the screen is a reasonable representation of what your print looked like. Save this gradient map as a preset. That way, the next time you want to print a photo, you can throw the gradient map on top of it as a preview of what your negative will look like after developing, and you can play around with adjustments (mostly sharpening, curves layer and HDR mapping I'd imagine) until you like how the preview looks, to make sure that neither the shadows nor the highlights will lose detail.

Regarding the section on the exposure time, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(photography). Basically, you should expect the density of the developed image to scale linearly with the log of exposure. When doing the test strips, most people would pick intervals like 30 seconds, 1 minute, 2 minutes, 4 minutes, etc. as a result. Finally, you're right to notice that the observed density didn't perfectly obey the reciprocity law -- sometimes the chemistry doesn't quite cooperate with the math. Not sure about the cyanotype process, but with the "normal" silver halide process a crystal has to absorb two photons to be able to darken during development. While the math suggests that on average the two photons will have arrived, sometimes that second photon doesn't actually show up. So what should be a crystal that will be developed... isn't actually. This is called reciprocity failure and has to be corrected for to get a properly exposed image. (The results are sometimes very surprising; for example 400 speed film being dramatically slower than 100 speed film out towards 1 minute or longer exposures. But it is very much a chemistry thing; some 100 speed film has very low reciprocity failure, like Acros 100.)

A better (less lossy) way to increase contrast would be to define your white and black points. So you find the darkest pixel in your image and define that as your black point, then you find the brightest pixel in the image that isn't a specular highlight and define that as your white point. This has the effect of stretching the histogram closer to the edges, therefore increasing contrast. Your way works too though :)
